text: That feature is provided by default in both vim and nvim. So you don't even need deoplete for that. What deoplete does is to automatically show a pop up with the suggestions whenever one or more characters are pressed. But in fact, you can trigger this menu  manually without deoplete: in insert mode (and inside a file with some text) type `CTRL-n` or `CTRL-p`. In fact, vanilla (n)vim provides a bunch of different types of completion. Checkout `:h ins-complete` to read about them. And yes, `completion-nvim` , like deoplete, can also use these sources for completion suggestions.

text: My main problem with vim is vimscript. It's an ad-hoc language not very well designed by 1 person and slow. Although nvim supports it, its plan is to slowly replace it with lua, which is faster and much nicer to program with. So yeah, I'm quite happy with my decision of jumping from vim to nvim. Translating a plugin from vimscript to lua immediately gives you nice speedups.

text: The other thing that I've never liked about vim is this idea of "benevolent dictator" role or whatever people call it that Bram Moolenaar has. Apparently, many vim users were asking for functionality that he did not want to implement. But as soon as nvim took off and implemented these wanted features, he started implementing them as well: embedded terminal,  asynchronous io. etc etc. He is the only one that commits to the vim repo.
